text:
BIOGRAPHIES OF NOMINEES
Copied (slightly abridged) from Who’s Who in America or Furnished by the Individual
CORBETT, PERCY E., dean faculty of law
b. Prince Edward Island, Canada, 1892; M.A., McGill, 1915-
Rhodes Scholar; member of Balliol College, Oxford; M.A., Oxford,
1925; fellow of All Souls College, Oxford, 1920-27; member of the
Secretariat of the League of Nations and Assistant Legal Adviser
to the International Labour Office, 1920-24; professor of Roman
law, McGill, 1924; dean of faculty of law, McGill, 1928-; leader
of Round Tables at Institute of Politics, Williamstown, 1929-32;
lecturer on Canadian-American relations at the Harris Foundation,
Chicago, 1930. Publications: Canada and World Politics (with
H. A. Smith); The Roman Law of Marriage; and articles in Ca¬
nadian, American and English Periodicals. Address: McGill
University, Montreal, Que., Canada.
CRANE, ROBERT TREAT, research director
b. at Baltimore, Md., 1880; ed. Marston’s University Sch., Balti¬
more; A.B., Johns Hopkins, 1902; Ph.D., 1907; LL.B.,U.of Md.,
1907. Fellow Johns Hopkins, 1905-06; admitted to Md. bar, 1907;
served as Am. consul, 1908-13; assistant professor political science,
1913-16, associate professor, 1916-18, professor, 1918-33, Univer¬
sity of Michigan; dir. Bur. of Government, same univ., 1913-
22; teacher summer sessions, Johns Hopkins, 1916, U. of Chicago,
1922, U. of Colo., 1923, Stanford, 1924, 25, also acting prof.,
U. of Chicago, 1922-23, Stanford, 1925-26. Exec. dir. Social
Science Research Council since 1931. Mem. Am. Assn. Univ.
Profs., Am. Polit. Science Assn., Am. Soc. Internat. Law, Alpha
Delta Phi, Phi Beta Kappa. Author: The State in Constitutional
and International Law, 1007; Digest of City-Manager Charters,
1923. Home: 108 E. 82d St. Office: 230 Park Avenue, New
York, N. Y.
GAUSS, CHRISTIAN, univ. dean
b. Ann Arbor, Mich., 1878; A.B., U. of Mich., 1898, A.M., 1899,
LL.D., 1933; Litt.D., Washington, 1914; L.H.D., Lehigh, 1928;
Instructor Romance langs., U. of Mich., 1899-1901; Lehigh U.,
1901-03; asst. prof. Modern langs., Lehigh U., 1903-05; asst,
prof. Romance langs., 1905-07, prof. Modern langs. since 1907
and chmn. dept, since 1913, dean of the College since 1925, Prince¬
ton. Non-resident lecturer on Ropes Foundation for Comparative
Lit., U. of Cincinnati, 1913; grad, lecturer. New York U., 1915-
16; lecturer, Columbia U. Inst. Arts and Sciences. Lit. editor
Princeton Alumni Weekly, 1914-20. Mem. Kappa Sigma, Phi
Beta Kappa; pres. Dante League America, 1918-20. Translator:
Ferrero’s The Women of the Caesars; (with Alice Gauss) Bain-
ville’s History of France, 1925. Editor: Selections from J. J.
Rousseau, 1914; Democracy Today, An American Interpretation,
1917; Flaubert’s Madame Bovary, 1930. Author: The German
Emperor, 1915; Through College on Nothing a Year, 1915; Why
We Went to War, 1918; Life in College, 1930. Home: Prihce-
ton, N. J.
MITCHELL, SAMUEL ALFRED, astronomer
b. Kingston, Can., 1874; M.A., Queen’s U., Can., 1894, LL.D.,
1924; Ph.D., Johns Hopkins, 1898; tutor in astronomy, 1899-
1905, instr., 1905-08, adj. prof., 1908-13, Columbia U.; prof, as¬
tronomy and dir. McCormick Obs., U. of Va., 1913-. Astronomer,
Eclipse Expdn. to Georgia, 1900, to Sumatra, 1901, to Spain, 1905,
to Ore., 1918, to Calif., 1923, to Conn., 1925, to Norway, 1927, to
Niuafoou Island, 1930, to Quebec, 1932; research asso. Yerkes
Observatory (U. of Chicago), summers, 1907, 09, 10, 11, assistant
professor of astrophysics, 1912-13. Fellow A.A.A.S., Am. Philos.
Soc., Am. Acad. Arts and Sciences, Nat. Acad. Arts and Sciences;
fellow and foreign asso. Royal Astron. Soc.; hon. mem. Am.
Assn. Variable Star Observers; mem. Am. Astron. Soc., National
Research Council, International Astron. Union (chmn. com. on
stellar parallaxes), Astronomisches Gesellschaft, Societe Astron-
omique de France, American Association University Professors
(chairman Committee A), Beta Theta Pi, Phi Beta Kappa, Sigma
Xi, Tau Beta Pi. Author: Parallaxes of 260 Stars, 1920; Eclipses
of the Sun, 1923, 4th edit., 1933; Parallaxes of 440 Stars, 1927;
Fundamentals of Astronomy (with C. G. Abbot), 1927; Solar
Eclipses, 1929. Address: Leander McCormick Observatory, Uni¬
versity, Va.
MOULTON, HAROLD GLENN, economist
b. LeRoy, Mich., 1883; Albion (Mich.) Coll., 1903-05; Ph.B.,
U. of Chicago, 1907, Ph.D., 1914; LL.D., Washington Univ.,
New York Univ., Univ. of Pittsburgh and George Washington
Univ., 1933. Instr. Evanston Acad., 1908-09; fellow in polit.
economy, 1909-10, traveling fellow, 1910, asst, in polit. economy,
1910-11, instr., 1911-14, asst, prof., 1914-18, asso. prof., 1918-22,
prof., 1922, U. of Chicago; dir. Inst, of Economics, Washington,
D. C., 1922-29; pres. The Brookings Institution (Washington)
since 1928. Mem. American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Author: Waterways vs. Railways, 1912 and 25; Principles of
Money and Banking, 1916; Financial Organization of Society,
1921, 3d edit., 1930; The Reparation Plan, 1924; Japan, An Eco¬
nomic and Financial Appraisal, 1931; The American Transporta¬
tion Problem, 1933. Joint Author: Readings in the Economics of
War, 1918; America and the Balance Sheet of Europe, 1921;
Germany’s Capacity to Pay, 1923; Russian Debts and Russian
Reconstruction, 1924; The French Debt Problem, 1925; World
War Debt Settlements, 1926; The St. Lawrence Navigation and
Power Project, 1929; War Debts and World Prosperity, 1932.
Contbr. to scientific and popular journals. Lecturer on economic
issues. Home: 3700 Oliver St., Washington, D. C.
57.3-10-35
